results.headline: Stomping His Way to Brotherhood

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Stomp the Yard

results.summary_short: "Stomp the Yard" is a strange and at times strangely compelling mix of black fraternity recruitment video and inspirational tale about a hip-hop boy in a stepping world.

results.headline: The Human and the Animated, Shrunk to Size

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Arthur and the Invisibles

results.summary_short: Luc Besson serves up a hybrid of live actors and computer-generated figures to tell a not-endearing-enough story about a boy who shrinks to microscopic size to find his missing grandfather.

results.headline: Just a Bunch of Kids Who Kidnap and Kill

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Alpha Dog

results.summary_short: "Alpha Dog" has much the same entertainment value you get from watching monkeys fling scat at one another in a zoo or reading the latest issue of Star magazine.

results.headline: The Unvarnished Reality of the Holocaust
results.display_title: Verdict on Auschwitz: The Frankfurt Auschwitz Trial 1963-1965

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Verdict on Auschwitz: The Frankfurt Auschwitz Trial 1963-1965

results.summary_short: Relying heavily on audiotapes from the trial, this documentary conveys the horrors of the Holocaust in a way even the best Hollywood movies can't.

results.headline: A Portrait of Lives Transformed by Trauma

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Abduction

results.summary_short: The documentary "Abduction: The Megumi Yokota Story" succeeds as a true crime story and is compassionate and engrossing throughout.

results.headline: The World Has Nearly Ended, but Movies Manage to Survive

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ever Since the World Ended

results.summary_short: “Ever Since the World Ended” is a faux documentary with a twist, a rudimentary yet fascinating record of remembrance and reconstruction.

results.headline: Two Views of Artists, Two Visions of the World
results.display_title: Agnes Martin: With My Back to the World

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Agnes Martin: With My Back to the World

results.summary_short: This pair of documentaries exploring two contemporary art visionaries is interesting in that it shows just how different artists' methods can be.

results.headline: Once Upon a Time, Flopsy and Mopsy, There Was a Plucky Proto-Feminist Who ...

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Miss Potter

results.summary_short: This film is the cinematic equivalent of a delicate English tea cake whose substance is buried under too many layers of icing.

results.headline: To Ms. With Love: A Teacher’s Heart Fords a Social Divide

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Freedom Writers

results.summary_short: In “Freedom Writers” Hilary Swank uses neediness to fine effect in a film with a strong emotional tug and smartly laid foundation.

results.headline: When a Woman Rattles a Man's World of Fraud

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Comedy of Power

results.summary_short: "Comedy of Power" is not Claude Chabrol's deepest or most ambitious film, but Isabelle Huppert's ferocity compensates for the director's detachment.

results.headline: A Man, a Corpse and No Memory

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Code Name: The Cleaner

results.summary_short: Cedric the Entertainer's artless performance deadens what could have been a much funnier comedy.

results.headline: A Fairy Tale for Fractured Times

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Happily N'Ever After

results.summary_short: Despite self-aware touches, this is another tired kidsploitation product in which a wasp-waisted ingénue and a shallow beau drive the plot and live happily ever.

results.headline: From Sex Trade to Vultures: Asia Outside In

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sacrifice

results.summary_short: Ellen Bruno's work takes risks with form to imply that individual suffering and transcendence are but particles in a river of spiritual energy that dwarfs geography and time.

results.headline: In Croatia, an Empty Life in Full View

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Love You

results.summary_short: “I Love You,” a bleak drama from the Croatian writer and director Dalibor Matanic, is an unusually perceptive scrutiny of absence and emptiness.

results.headline: In Gloom of War, a Child's Paradise

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pan's Labyrinth

results.summary_short: "Pan's Labyrinth" is a political fable in the guise of a fairy tale. Or maybe it's the other way around.

results.headline: Dude, Where’s My Girlfriend? Poet Pines in War-Torn Iraq

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Tiger and the Snow

results.summary_short: Roberto Benigni's film is a scorching affront to Italians, Iraqis and the intelligence of movie audiences everywhere.

results.headline: A Body Is Discovered in a Wasteland of Emotions

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Dead Girl

results.summary_short: The relentless emotional violence in this film, a compendium of five vignettes related to a young woman whose corpse is discovered on a hillside, is of a level rarely found in movies.

results.headline: A Friendship Develops, and Obsession Follows

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Notes on a Scandal

results.summary_short: Judi Dench and Cate Blanchett star in a misanthropic game of cat and mouse from which no one emerges unscathed, including saps like us who think we’re watching a film about other people.

results.headline: The Sweet Smell of Life That Drives Him to Kill
results.display_title: Perfume: the Story of A Murderer

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Perfume: the Story of A Murderer

results.summary_short: Try as it might to be refined and provocative, Tom Tykwer's “Perfume” never rises above the pedestrian creepiness of its conceit.

results.headline: Psycho Killer Holiday Tip: Use Eyeballs as Ornaments

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Black Christmas

results.summary_short: Glen Morgan’s disastrous remake smothers terror beneath a blanket of unnecessary information, revealing too much and teasing too little.
